attributes.comment:
While modest fee increases for government services are to be expected, the
proposed fee increases for immigration services are neither modest nor fair. It
is clear that the government is trying to pass along the cost of increased
security mandated by the government after 9/11 on to both citizens and
would-be-citizens. Obviously the president and the administration did not budget
sufficient funds to cover all the increased costs associated with creating the
new homeland security department, increasing border security, and tightening all
manner of immigration regulations. The funding deficits are now being passed on
to the consumers, who had no say in the new govt policies and units.

I am particularly opposed to the proposed 23% increase in the filing fee for the
I-600/I-600A form, the Petition for Advance Processing of Orphans. International
adoption is already an outrageously expensive undertaking, and raising the fees
by this inordinate amount when the fee increases over previous two 4-year
periods have been between 14% and 18%, and the last such fee increase was less
than two years ago, is adding an unfair burden to what is already a substantial
financial hardship for many families.

I am strongly opposed to this fee increase, and believe USCIS should not
penalize citizens trying to adopt orphans from developing countries by raising
this fee over 20% in an attempt to recover more of its increased costs since
9/11. Those costs must be born by the administration that mandated the changes.

Respectfully,

Rita C. Simpson-Vlach
Santa Clara, CA

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Rita Simpson-Vlach
